Best friend of my daughter is asking me about this. I feel obliged to clarify. I largely agree with @Armaros and @EebstertheGreat. Just want to elaborate a bit more.
First thing first, a = F/m. a is the acceleration in question. m is the mess of jumper. Given he doesn't pee or fart in between, we can assume his mess, m, doesn't change:) We can simply focus on F.
There are different forces pulling the jumper.
1. Fg - The gravity. Given consistent mess of jumper and the very short distance of movement compared to radius of the Earth, we can assume it doesn't change. Let's use its direction as positive.
2. Fr - The pulling force of bungee rope. Its direction is opposite to gravity. Its magnitude changed along the way.
3. Fa - Air resistance pointed out by @EebstertheGreat . It is small compared with the other two. But we should still take into consideration. It is a bit nasty that its direction is opposite of the moving direction. When jumper is moving down, its direction is opposite to Fg. When he bounced back, its direction is same as Fg.

Now let's exam the force on jumper for all choices with an important assumption that the weight of rope doesn't count:

a) F = Fg. The rope hasn't begun to pull. Fr is 0. Fa is also 0 because of the 0 speed.

b) F= Fg - Fr - Fa. Both Fr and Fa are still small. Fg > (Fr + Fa). abs(F) < abs(Fg)

c) F= 0. Since jumper reached max speed at c. That means Fr + Fa just matched Fg and began to overtake. Fa reached its maximum value at this point. Fr will keep growing when the rope is stretched further.

d) F = Fg - Fr. Fa is 0 due to 0 speed.

e) The video simply said e is 'on the rebound'. This is not clear. Rebound is a long process from the d to the point he reached maximum height, which let's call it f) to simplify the discussion. Before jumper reached f)

F = Fg - Fr + Fa. Fr reduced to 0 in the process. That is where you saw the rope looks like a shape of J.

f) F = Fg.

Overall Fa is way smaller than Fg and Fr. We can ignore until we compare two number only differed by Fa.
Also, the acceleration could be either direct just like F itself. We have to compare abs(F)

Now let's pick the answer.
a) ties with f)
c) won't be the answer obviously.
e) won't be the answer because Fr in e) smaller than Fr in d) When Fa is noticeable, Fr is already way smaller.

Now let's focus on d). If abs(Fr) > 2 * abs(Fg), then it is the answer. As many already pointed out. There is no guarantee. From the video, the upward acceleration from bottom up didn't seem to be greater than the downward acceleration when he started either. But I am not 100% sure.

Without knowing the properties of the bungee cord we cannot determine whether maximum acceleration occurs at initial jump or at the bottom of the jumper's travel.
Think of the forces acting on the jumper, where:

F = Net sum of forces
m = mass of jumper
a = acceleration
g = gravitational constant
k = spring constant of "ideal" bungee cord.
x = stretched distance of bungee cord.

For simplicity we'll neglect the effect of air resistance and the small effect that the mass of the bungee cord itself imparts.
Positive acceleration is downwards.

F=m.a
=> a=F/m
=> a=(m.g-k.x)/m (remember x is zero until bungee starts stretching)
i.e a=g-k.x/m

So initial acceleration is "g". We do not have enough information to determine whether the maximum (well minimum with our directional convention) acceleration is ever of greater magnitude than g.

N.B. I gather in the real (typical) world bungee jumpers usually experience between 2 & 3 gs at the bottom of the jump, however from the mathematics we can see that this does not have to be so.

I'm going to side with everyone who says it depends on the properties of the bungee (and the mass of the jumper).

The bungee begins to exert force opposite gravity the moment it becomes taught. The force it exerts will increase (exponentially) the more it is stretched which decreases the net downward force thereby decreasing acceleration (velocity continues to increase). At some point along the path the force becomes equal to the force of gravity but momentum pushes the jumper past that point. This is the point at which three jumper reaches max velocity and zero acceleration. The force the bungee exerts on the jumper continues to increase as the jumper passes the point of balanced forces creating an increasing net upward force and the jumper begins accelerating in the opposite direction (even though direction of travel is still downward). However, unless the absolute force exerted on the jumper from the bungee EXCEEDS twice the force exerted by gravity, acceleration will not be greater than free fall even at the moment the jumper changes direction. A heavier jumper will stretch the bungee further than a lightweight jumper thereby experiencing greater upward force at the bottom of the dive but not necessarily experiencing a net force greater than gravity.

Since practical considerations make it imperative that jumpers do not reach the maximum possible length of the bungee (resulting in acceleration rates similar to a car vs train collision), it may be assumed that the bungee is designed to keep even the heaviest jumper far from that point, I would (blindly) guess that the absolute force exerted on the average jumper from the bungee isn't going to be much more than twice that of gravity. Just a guess though. There is absolutely no way of knowing without knowing some real (elaborately measured) numbers.

Unfortunately, this answer is wrong.  It is a classic spring/dampener system, in which displacement, velocity, and acceleration ALL look like a sine wave that gets smaller and smaller and smaller.  The wave is always the largest at the very beginning.  That means that at t=0, displacement and acceleration are maximum, but velocity is 0 because it's phase shifted (think of it as instead of drawing a wave starting at its peak, you start drawing it at the center line)
